nodes.text: Differences in colonial experience caused by settler mortality produced lasting variation in institutions, and this institutional variation is a major causal determinant of current differences in income per capita

European colonization policies varied: some colonies were settled by Europeans (Neo-Europes) with institutions protecting property rights and checks on power, while others became extractive states with weak property rights
The feasibility of European settlement was strongly influenced by the disease environment: high settler mortality reduced settlement and favored extractive institutions
Colonial-era institutions persisted after independence and formed the basis of current institutions
Empirical strategy: use historical settler mortality (soldiers, bishops, sailors from 17th–19th centuries) as an instrument for current institutions to estimate institutions' causal effect on income

Mortality data come mainly from Curtin and related historical sources (annualized deaths per 1,000 mean strength for troops, bishops, sailors; supplemented for Latin America), representing potential settler mortality
First-stage result: log settler mortality explains a large and statistically significant share of cross-country variation in current institutions (about 25–30 percent of variation)

Instrumental-variable (2SLS) result: institutions have a large, statistically significant causal effect on log income per capita (baseline 2SLS approx 0.94; implies large long-run gains from improving institutions)
OLS evidence: strong positive correlation between measures of protection against expropriation and income per capita across countries (high R2), but subject to endogeneity and measurement error
Reduced-form observation: strong negative relationship between settler mortality and contemporary GDP per capita across sampled ex-colonies (higher mortality associated with lower current income)

Robustness: 2SLS estimates are robust to controlling for many potential confounders (latitude, continent dummies, legal origin, religion, climate, natural resources, soil quality, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, current disease measures, fraction European descent)

Overidentification and other tests: adding alternative instruments (European settlement share, early institutions measures) and overidentification tests provide no evidence that settler mortality affects current income other than through institutions

Historical evidence: contemporary accounts and archival records document very high European mortality in many colonies (e.g., Sierra Leone, Bulama, expeditions), and recorded decisions (Pilgrims, Beauchamp Committee) that avoided high-mortality locations

Historical examples support mechanism: settler colonies (United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand) developed institutions favoring private property, while extractive regimes (Belgian Congo, many African and Latin American colonies) prioritized resource extraction and weak property rights

Limitation/caveat: main validity concern is that settler mortality may proxy for the current disease environment (directly affecting income); authors argue this is unlikely because native adults often had acquired immunity and because robustness checks (malaria, yellow fever instruments) do not overturn results

Conclusion: empirical evidence supports that colonial settler mortality shaped institutions which causally affect long-run economic performance; improving institutions can produce substantial income gains, though mechanisms for institutional change require further analysis
